Yeh I remember you saying this a while ago but never got around to 
looking into it. Do you use plain tanh e.g. y=tanh(x) , or some 
variation? The reason I ask is that while playing around with gnuplot I 
noticed that tanh describes a sigmoid over the y range -1,1 whereas I 
have been using functions with a y range of 0,1

The distinction is quite important because with a minimum of zero, 
negative connection weights have the effect of damping other inputs, 
e.g. a large negative input signal will cancel out any other signals and 
give an output of 0. That 0 can not then go on to activate further 
neurons. In contrast tanh will output -1, which is a signal that can go 
on to have influence as it propagates through the network.

I don't know enough to say whether this is bad or not, but it at least 
seems like an important distinction to make.

Anyway I most often use the steepened sigmoid function from one of Ken's 
papers:

y = 1/1+exp(-4.9*x))

and this looks exactly the same as tanh after applying a bit of scaling 
and shifting:

y = tanh(2.45*x)/2 + 0.5

My maths isn't great, but I would guess these can be proven to be 
mathematically equivalent.

Colin
